tn.ref: This is the word of Yahweh that came to
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]].
A potter is someone who makes pots and other useful, small things from clay. AT: "the workshop of the potter"
The word "behold" alerts us to a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.
The potter's wheel is a small table that spins, a potter uses it to make pots. AT: "at his table" or "to make pots"
"forming" or "shaping"
AT: "fell apart in his hand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
AT: "so he made a different choice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The eyes stand for the potter himself. AT: "good to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the word of Yahweh came to
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]].

tn.ref: Should I not be able to act like this potter with you, house of Israel?
tn.text: With this question, Yahweh emphasizes his authority to do as he pleases with Israel. AT: "I am allowed to act toward you, house of Israel, like the potter acts toward the clay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
The word "see" here adds emphasis to what follows. AT: "Indeed!"

tn.ref: Like clay in a potter's hand—that is how you are in my hand
tn.text: This phrase repeats what was implicit in the previous phrase in the form of a simile. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
AT: "perhaps I proclaim something" or "for example, I proclaim something"

tn.ref: tear it down, or destroy it
tn.text: These two expressions basically mean the same thing and emphasize how destructive God's judgment will be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"withhold" AT: "not bring"

tn.ref: build it up or plant it
tn.text: These two verbs basically mean the same thing and emphasize God's blessing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This phrase compares God's blessing to carefully placing a plant in a garden. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The eyes of Yahweh refer to Yahweh himself. AT: "things that I consider to be evil" or "evil according to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
AT: "not obeying my commands" or "not paying attention to what I said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

tn.ref: I am about to form disaster against you. I am about to devise a plan against you
tn.text: Both of these sentences describe the same thing to emphasize how dangerous this warning is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh refers to disaster as something he forms as a person would form clay. AT: "shape" or "create" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"think of " or "plan" or "create"
AT: "his wicked way of living" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The words "ways" and "practices" basically mean the same thing and emphasize that their whole way of living has to change. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The word "they" refers to the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.
AT: "We have no hope"

tn.ref: what his evil, stubborn heart desires
tn.text: This person is referred to by the part of his body associated with emotions. AT: "by his wicked desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Ask the nations, who has ever heard of such a thing as this?
tn.text: This question stands for a statement. AT: "Nowhere on earth has anyone ever heard of such a thing like this." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

It was common to refer to nations as if they were women. However, "virgin" makes a person think about a young woman who has never married and so has never had the opportunity to be faithless to her husband. Therefore, calling Israel a virgin is an ironic use of language. AT: "Israel, who falsely pretends to be fully devoted to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])

tn.ref: Does the snow in Lebanon ever leave the rocky hills on its sides?
tn.text: This question stands for a statement. AT: "The snow of Lebanon clearly never leaves the rocky hills on its sides" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Are the mountain streams coming from far away ever destroyed?
tn.text: This question stands for a statement. AT: "Nothing can ever destroy those mountain streams coming from far away." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here the word "their" refers to "my people."
AT: "will become something that horrifies people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is a sound that shows strong disapproval.
Here the word "her" refers to "Their land."

tn.ref: I will scatter them before their enemies like an eastern wind
tn.text: Yahweh compares himself to wind from the east that scatters dust and debris. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here the word "them" refers to "my people."

tn.ref: I will show them my back, and not my face
tn.text: This action symbolizes that God will refuse to help his people.

tn.ref: let us make plots against Jeremiah
tn.text: "let us make plans to harm Jeremiah"

tn.ref: the law will never perish from the priests, or advice from the wise men, or words from the prophets
tn.text: AT: "the priests will always have the law, the wise men will always give advice, and the prophets will always speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"say things that will harm him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here Jeremiah begins speaking to Yahweh.

tn.ref: Will disaster from them really be my reward for being good to them?
tn.text: Jeremiah asks this question to emphasize that good actions should not be repaid with bad things. AT: "Disaster from them should not be my reward for being good to them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
AT: "dug a pit to trap me and kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: to cause your fury to turn away from them
tn.text: AT: "so that you would not punish them in your anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: give them over to the power of the sword
tn.text: "Sword" represents warfare. AT: "cause them to die in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: let their women become bereaved and widows
tn.text: "let the children and husbands of their women die"

tn.ref: their men be killed, and their young men killed by the sword
tn.text: AT: "people kill their men, and kill their young men with swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "people hear a distressed shout" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: For they have dug a pit to capture me and have hidden traps for my feet
tn.text: Jeremiah's enemies are trying to capture him like a person would capture a wild animal. Jeremiah repeats the same idea twice for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:18:18|18:20]].

tn.ref: Do not wipe their sins away from you
tn.text: This phrase means the same thing as the previous phrase. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: let them be overthrown before you
tn.text: AT: "let people overthrow them in your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
